messages.content:
Objective: Write code for a large system design task.

You must act autonomously and you will receive no human input at any stage. You have to return as output the complete code for completing this task, and correctly incorporate it into the existing code base.

You always write out the whole file contents. You always indent code with tabs.

When modifying code and including new code, you must use the diff format using the line numbers.
Please always view the files before writing to them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.
If you are unsure, you can list all available files to view with the `list_files` function.

Provide the minimal code necessary to achieve the task conditioned on the existing generated code---including changing the existing generated code.

You cannot visualize any graphical output. You exist within a Actor Model machine, and when you list out steps, each step will be taken by a new separate sub-ChatGPT model. When you list out a sub-task steps, you can optionally specify the sub-task validation to check that it has been completed successfully.

You can write to local files, however you cannot use any databases, as none are setup in the local environment.

Use the functions provided. When calling functions only provide a RFC8259 compliant JSON request following this format without deviation.

You will get instructions for code to write.
You will write a very long answer. Make sure that every detail of the architecture is, in the end, implemented as code.

Think step by step and reason yourself to the right decisions to make sure we get it right.
First lay out the names of the core classes, functions, methods that will be necessary, As well as a quick comment on their purpose.

Do not comment on what every file does. Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

You will start with the "entrypoint" file, then go to the ones that are imported by that file, and so on.
Please note that the code should be fully functional. No placeholders.

Follow a language and framework appropriate best practice file naming convention.
Make sure that files contain all imports, types etc.  The code should be fully functional. Make sure that code in different files are compatible with each other.
When writing code if you are unsure, write a plausible implementation.
Include module dependency or package manager dependency definition file.

Useful to know:

Always use the programming language the user asks for.
For Python, you always create an appropriate requirements.txt file.
For NodeJS, you always create an appropriate package.json file.
Always add a comment briefly describing the purpose of the function definition.
Add comments explaining very complex bits of logic.
Always follow the best practices for the requested languages for folder/file structure and how to package the project.
You can use any package and any other packages you wish to install.

Python toolbelt preferences:
- pytest
- dataclasses

Objective:```
Write complete MVC code for the following system design task.  Design a URL Shortening Service (TinyURL)
Features to implement:
1. Given a long URL, the service should generate a shorter and unique alias for it.
2. When the user hits a short link, the service should redirect to the original link.
3. Support for custom short URLs.
4. Track click stats.
5. Delete expired URLs.
```

Understand the problem, by creating a detailed step-by-step plan. Try to solve the problem in the minimal steps necessary, in no more than 10 steps. Create additional tests, checks and evaluation at each step when applicable to help make excellent code implementation, where all the code is fully functional. Use best software design practices, and you can output large amounts of code at once. The last step should be running any tests automatically if they exist, and the penultimate step writing these tests. You will receive no human input at any stage, so you cannot use a human to test. Only create a detailed plan to begin with, which includes designing and running tests to check that they all pass.

function_call.name: provide_detailed_sub_task_steps_for_sub_agents
function_call.arguments:
{
  "steps": [
    "Step 1: Create a Python Flask application with the necessary routes for the URL shortening service. The routes should include: a route for creating a short URL, a route for redirecting from a short URL to the original URL, a route for tracking click stats, and a route for deleting expired URLs.",
    "Step 2: Implement the model for the URL shortening service. This should include a class for the URL with attributes for the original URL, the short URL, the creation date, and the click count.",
    "Step 3: Implement the controller for the URL shortening service. This should include methods for creating a short URL, redirecting from a short URL to the original URL, tracking click stats, and deleting expired URLs.",
    "Step 4: Implement the view for the URL shortening service. This should include methods for displaying the short URL, redirecting to the original URL, displaying click stats, and confirming the deletion of expired URLs.",
    "Step 5: Implement the logic for generating a unique short URL. This could be done by using a hash function on the original URL and then converting the hash to a base62 string to get a short and unique URL.",
    "Step 6: Implement the logic for redirecting from a short URL to the original URL. This could be done by looking up the short URL in the database and then redirecting to the original URL.",
    "Step 7: Implement the logic for tracking click stats. This could be done by incrementing the click count each time a short URL is accessed.",
    "Step 8: Implement the logic for deleting expired URLs. This could be done by checking the creation date of each URL and deleting it if it is older than a certain threshold.",
    "Step 9: Write tests for each of the routes and methods in the URL shortening service. These tests should check that the routes and methods behave as expected and handle edge cases correctly.",
    "Step 10: Run the tests and fix any issues that arise. Once all the tests pass, the URL shortening service is ready to be deployed."
  ]
}

messages.content:
Objective: Execute task step: Step 10: Run the tests and fix any issues that arise. Once all the tests pass, the URL shortening service is ready to be deployed. 

 Note: Condition any new code files on the existing code files: ['app.py', 'requirements.txt', 'models.py', 'controller.py', 'test_app.py']. You can now optionally view the existing files if you need to view them to complete the current task step. You have a limited context window so be selective about which files you view, only view the files you think you might need to view.

messages.name: pytest_files
messages.content:
{"output": "============================= test session starts ==============================
platform linux -- Python 3.9.7, pytest-7.4.2, pluggy-1.3.0
rootdir: /tmp/tmplg4ckz80
plugins: hydra-core-1.3.2, anyio-3.7.0
collected 4 items

test_app.py ....                                                         [100%]

============================== 4 passed in 0.04s ==============================="}

Has the task been completed of: ```
Step 10: Run the tests and fix any issues that arise. Once all the tests pass, the URL shortening service is ready to be deployed.
``` 

 If yes, return ACCEPT, otherwise reflect and return the full complete corrected code to complete the task, use the defined functions to write the code. Condition it on existing code: ['app.py', 'requirements.txt', 'models.py', 'controller.py', 'test_app.py']. If you have not viewed the files before writing to them, please view them, to make sure you are writing to the correct files.

app.py: from flask import Flask, request, redirect, jsonify
models.py: self.creation_date = creation_date if creation_date else datetime.now()
controller.py: # Generate a unique short URL by hashing the original URL
# Get the original URL from the short URL
# Get the click stats for a short URL
# Delete URLs that are older than the expiry days
expired_urls = [short_url for short_url, url in self.urls.items() if url.creation_date < expiry_date]
test_app.py: from app import app as flask_app

steps: Step 1: Create a Python Flask application with the necessary routes for the URL shortening service. The routes should include: a route for creating a short URL, a route for redirecting from a short URL to the original URL, a route for tracking click stats, and a route for deleting expired URLs.
Step 2: Implement the model for the URL shortening service. This should include a class for the URL with attributes for the original URL, the short URL, the creation date, and the click count.

Step 3: Implement the controller for the URL shortening service. This should include methods for creating a short URL, redirecting from a short URL to the original URL, tracking click stats, and deleting expired URLs.

Step 4: Implement the view for the URL shortening service. This should include methods for displaying the short URL, redirecting to the original URL, displaying click stats, and confirming the deletion of expired URLs.

Step 5: Implement the logic for generating a unique short URL. This could be done by using a hash function on the original URL and then converting the hash to a base62 string to get a short and unique URL.
Step 6: Implement the logic for redirecting from a short URL to the original URL. This could be done by looking up the short URL in the database and then redirecting to the original URL.
Step 7: Implement the logic for tracking click stats. This could be done by incrementing the click count each time a short URL is accessed.
Step 8: Implement the logic for deleting expired URLs. This could be done by checking the creation date of each URL and deleting it if it is older than a certain threshold.
Step 9: Write tests for each of the routes and methods in the URL shortening service. These tests should check that the routes and methods behave as expected and handle edge cases correctly.
Step 10: Run the tests and fix any issues that arise. Once all the tests pass, the URL shortening service is ready to be deployed.
step: Step 10: Run the tests and fix any issues that arise. Once all the tests pass, the URL shortening service is ready to be deployed.

function_call.arguments:
{
  "steps": [
    "Step 1: Create a Python Flask application with the necessary routes for the URL shortening service. The routes should include: a route for creating a short URL, a route for redirecting from a short URL to the original URL, a route for tracking click stats, and a route for deleting expired URLs.",
    "Step 2: Implement the model for the URL shortening service. This should include a class for the URL with attributes for the original URL, the short URL, the creation date, and the click count.",
    "Step 3: Implement the controller for the URL shortening service. This should include methods for creating a short URL, redirecting from a short URL to the original URL, tracking click stats, and deleting expired URLs.",
    "Step 4: Implement the view for the URL shortening service. This should include methods for displaying the short URL, redirecting to the original URL, displaying click stats, and confirming the deletion of expired URLs.",
    "Step 5: Implement the logic for generating a unique short URL. This could be done by using a hash function on the original URL and then converting the hash to a base62 string to get a short and unique URL.",
    "Step 6: Implement the logic for redirecting from a short URL to the original URL. This could be done by looking up the short URL in the database and then redirecting to the original URL.",
    "Step 7: Implement the logic for tracking click stats. This could be done by incrementing the click count each time a short URL is accessed.",
    "Step 8: Implement the logic for deleting expired URLs. This could be done by checking the creation date of each URL and deleting it if it is older than a certain threshold.",
    "Step 9: Write tests for each of the routes and methods in the URL shortening service. These tests should check that the routes and methods behave as expected and handle edge cases correctly.",
    "Step 10: Run the tests and fix any issues that arise. Once all the tests pass, the URL shortening service is ready to be deployed."
  ]
}
